normalised: I-I-T Delhi just dropped a bombshell! Turns out, solving linear algebra problems using traditional methods is so last season. They've developed a new algorithm that's supposedly five times faster for massive matrices. Professor Gupta, lead researcher, said it's a "game changer" for fields like A-I and data science. Imagine crunching those complex datasets in a fraction of the time!

unnormalised: The team's focusing on improving efficiency in matrix decomposition, a core operation. They claim their method cuts down computational complexity from O(n^3) to something closer to O(n^2.5). Big deal for anyone dealing with million-by-million matrices. Plus, they're saying it can be implemented on standard hardware, no fancy quantum computers needed (yet!).
normalised: The team's focusing on improving efficiency in matrix decomposition, a core operation. They claim their method cuts down computational complexity from O of n cubed to something closer to O of n to the power of two point five. Big deal for anyone dealing with million-by-million matrices. Plus, they're saying it can be implemented on standard hardware, no fancy quantum computers needed (yet!).

unnormalised: Early benchmarks are promising. They compared their algo against industry standard solvers like LAPACK and showed significant speedups on matrices with dimensions ranging from 1000x1000 to 10000x10000. Apparently, the biggest gains were seen when dealing with sparse matrices, which are common in real-world applications. Tests showed a 3x to 5x performance jump on average, which is huge.
